metadata.case_name: Indian Engineering Company v. Keshavsinh Dwarkadas Kapadia

facts.text: On 16 September 1965, Kapadia appointed Chetan Trading Company as sole selling agent for several products including aluminium and copper wire.
Chetan Trading Company appointed Indian Engineering Company as their sole selling agent in respect of aluminium and copper wires.
Chetan Trading Company terminated their agreement with Indian Engineering Company.
Kapadia terminated the sole selling agency with Chetan Trading Company.

Indian Engineering Company contended that on termination of sole selling agency between themselves and Chetan Trading Company, Indian Engineering Company became the sole selling agent of Kapadia in terms of agreement dated 16 September 1965.
Indian Engineering Company claimed damages against Kapadia for breach of the agreement.
Kapadia claimed damages and moneys from Indian Engineering Company.
Disputes arose between Indian Engineering Company and Kapadia; referred to arbitration by agreement dated 26 April 1967.
Similar arbitration agreement between Chetan Trading Company and Indian Engineering Company dated 5 June 1967 with identical arbitrators.

Arbitration agreement clauses: Clause 1 refers disputes to Shri H.G. Advani and Shri J.N. Gandhi; Clause 2 governed by Arbitration Act 1940; Clause 5: award within 4 months of entering reference, extendable with consent; Clause 6: arbitrators to appoint umpire before proceeding, refer to umpire on difference.
Arbitrators held first meeting on 12 September 1967 and appointed Mr. Porus Mehta (failing him Mr. Murzban Mistry) as umpire before entering upon reference.
Time for award under Clause 5 expired on 11 January 1968.
On 14 January 1968, respondents wrote to appellants for extension of time; appellants did not reply.
On 6 March 1968, appellants wrote to arbitrators alleging bias of Mr. Advani towards respondents.
Respondents called upon arbitrators to refer to umpire and upon umpire Mr. Porus A. Mehta to enter on reference.
Mr. Mehta fixed meeting on 27 May 1968; adjourned due to appellants' objections.
Meeting fixed on 17 June 1968; Mr. Mehta gave directions and fixed 12 July 1968 for hearing.
On 12 July 1968, appellants contended no consent of umpire obtained before appointment, invalid appointment.
Mr. Mehta fixed 13 July 1968, proceeded, adjourned to 20 July 1968.
Appellants obtained adjournment to file petition challenging appointment; adjourned to 30 July 1968.
Appellants filed applications under section 33 Arbitration Act leading to Bombay High Court order dated 17 October 1968: umpire rightly entered reference, time extended to 31 December 1968.

legal_issues.text: Whether there can be any valid appointment of umpire by arbitrators without obtaining consent of the appointee to be an umpire.

On the construction of the arbitration agreement, was the operation of paragraph 4 of Schedule I of the Arbitration Act excluded with the result that the umpire could enter upon the reference only in the event of a difference arising between the arbitrators.

petitioner_arguments.text: Arbitrators did not obtain consent of umpire before appointment, therefore no valid appointment of umpire.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 8 Arbitration Act 1940; Russell on Arbitration 18th Ed. p212; Ringland v. Lowndes; Tradax Export S.A. v. Volkswagenwerk A.G.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under clause 6 of arbitration agreement, operation of paragraph 4 Schedule I Arbitration Act excluded; umpire could enter reference only on difference between arbitrators; no difference arose, only time expired.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Clause 6 arbitration agreement; para 4 Schedule I Arbitration Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Under clause 6, umpire had no right to enter reference unless arbitrators referred the matter to umpire.
Words 'if any appointed arbitrator or umpire neglects or refuses to act' in section 8(1) Arbitration Act mean refusal only after acceptance.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 8(1) Arbitration Act 1940; Russell on Arbitration

respondent_arguments.text: Sought extension of time for award.
Called upon arbitrators to refer to umpire and umpire to enter reference.

court_reasoning.text: Appointment of umpire by arbitrators does not require prior consent of appointee; consent signified by taking up office; distinction between appointment and acceptance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arbitrators completed appointment before entering reference; umpire's authority commenced when entered upon reference.

court_reasoning.text: No authority requires consent before appointment; acceptance may be express or implied by conduct; Tradax and Ringland distinguished as special clauses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appointment effective upon acceptance, but prior consent not needed.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 6 does not exclude para 4 Schedule I; no expressed different intention; time expiry allows umpire to enter in lieu of arbitrators.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement intended umpire to act if arbitrators fail to award in time.

court_reasoning.text: Disagreement between arbitrators existed due to appellants' attitude alleging bias, preventing progress; time also expired.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expiry of time and disagreement both trigger umpire.

holdings.text: Valid appointment of umpire without prior consent; umpire rightly entered upon reference.
Clause 6 does not exclude para 4 Schedule I Arbitration Act; umpire can enter on time expiry or disagreement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mirza Sadik Husain v. Mussanmat Kaniz Zohra Begam
precedents_cited.relevance: Refusal to act includes refusal to accept; applies to Arbitration Act.
Special statutory features requiring consent for court appointment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tradax Export S.A. v. Volkswagenwerk A.G.
precedents_cited.relevance: Centrocon clause requires effective appointment with acceptance within time limit.
Parties need not approve arbitrators' choice of umpire.
Appointment by arbitrators is act of will.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs arbitration; para 4 allows umpire to enter on time expiry unless excluded; s8 on refusal to act; s33 for challenges.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Refusal to act includes refusal to accept; construction applies to Arbitration Act.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; High Court order upheld that umpire validly appointed and entered reference; time for award extended to three months from service of order.
outcome.relief_granted: Umpire Porus A. Mehta granted three months from date of service of order to make award.

key_quotes.text: Appointment of umpire by two arbitrators means that the arbitrators are to concur in appointing an umpire.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The umpire signified the consent by taking up the office and the umpire rightly entered on the reference.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court holding upheld on consent.

key_quotes.text: There is no authority for the proposition that consent of the appointee is required before an umpire is appointed by the arbitrators.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Clause 6 of the arbitration agreement does not state that only in the event of a difference arising between the arbitrators there shall be a reference to the umpire.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No exclusion of para 4 Schedule I.
